name: CloudConvert modules
title: CloudConvert modules

children.text: After connecting to the CloudConvert app, you can use the following modules to build your
Converts a specified file to the selected file format.

data.label: CloudConvert
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your CloudConvert account.

children.text: the file will be uploaded from.

manually or by mapping the file from a previous module. E.g.
Enter or map the file data.
Enter the file name including the file extension. E.g. test.txt
Enter the URL of the file you want to convert.
Define request headers (optional). Useful, for example, when the specified URL requires the authorization.
Select whether you want to specify the input format of the file you want to convert. If not specified, the extension of the input file is used as the input format.
Select the current format of the file.
Select the target file format you want to convert the file to.
Choose a filename (including extension) for the target output file.
Specify conversion and engine specific options. To view available options, please visit their
Enable this option to include also file data in the module's output.
Captures a specified website and saves it in PDF, JPG, or PNG format.

data.label: CloudConvert
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your CloudConvert account.

children.text: Enter the URL of the website you want to capture.
Select whether you want to save the captured website in PNG, JPG, or PDF format.
Enter a filename (including extension) for the target output file.
Define request headers (optional). Useful, for example, when the specified URL requires the authorization.
Specify conversion and engine specific options. To view available options, please visit their
Enable this option to include also file data in the module's output.
Optimizes and compresses a file. Currently supported formats are PDF, PNG and JPG.

Select the optimization profile for specific target needs.
Remove redundant and unnecessary data for the web
Down-sample, clip, and intelligently compress images
Remove redundant and unnecessary data for printing
Down-sample, clip, and intelligently compress images
Remove redundant and unnecessary data for archiving
Profile optimized for PDFs that mainly consist of raster images
Compress the images without significantly reducing the visual quality

Enter the file name (including extension) for the target output file.
Specify conversion and engine specific options. To view available options, please visit their
Enable this option to include also file data in the module's output.
Enables you to add one or multiple files to the ZIP, RAR, 7Z, TAR, TAR.GZ or TAR.BZ2 archive.

children.text: Add the files you want to use within the job.
Enter the source file by adding the
manually or by mapping the file from a previous module. E.g.
- Enter or map the file data.
- Enter the file name including the file extension. E.g. test.txt
- Enter the URL of the file you want to process.
Define request headers (optional). Useful, for example, when the specified URL requires the authorization.
Add tasks that will be performed within the job.
Please find the descriptions of the operations' fields in the corresponding section.
Export a File to Temporary URL (specify the
An arbitrary string to identify the job. Does not have any effect and can be used to associate the job with an ID.
If working with the Array Aggregator (e.g. you have many files in different formats to convert), use the
I don't know the input format
dialog. Otherwise the error is returned.
Retrieves all jobs that have been run in your account.

data.label: CloudConvert
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your CloudConvert account.

children.text: Select the job status to filter returned jobs by.
Set the number of returned jobs Make will return during one execution cycle.

data.label: CloudConvert
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your CloudConvert account.

children.text: Enter (map) the ID of the job you want to retrieve details about.
Deletes a job, including all tasks and data.
Jobs are deleted automatically 24 hours after they have ended.

data.label: CloudConvert

Retrieves all tasks in your account based on filter settings.

to return only tasks within the specified job.

Creates a new task, based on the settings (payload) of another task.

Allows you to perform a custom API call.

data.label: CloudConvert
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your CloudConvert account.

children.text: Enter a path relative to https://api.cloudconvert.com/. For example: /v2/tasks
For the list of available endpoints, refer to the
Select the HTTP method you want to use:
- to retrieve information for an entry.
- to make a partial entry update.
Enter the desired request headers. You don't have to add authorization headers; we already did that for you.
Enter the body content for your API call.
The following API call returns all tasks from your CloudFront account:
Matches of the search can be found in the module's Output under Bundle > Body > data.
In our example, 6 tasks were returned:

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
